Input Answer: To begin a journey or expedition.

English_passages: 1 set forth evidence. 2  set forth in a will. 3  set forth in words. 4  set forth on. 5  set forth the character of. 6  set forth the meaning. 7  set forward. 8  set forward. 9  set forward. 10

1. To put in a specified position or arrangement; place: set a book on a table; set the photo next to the flowers. 2. a. To put into a specified state: set the prisoner at liberty; set the house ablaze; set the machine in motion.

Context example: set forth one's reasons. Hypernyms (to set forth is one way to...): dilate; elaborate; enlarge; expand; expatiate; exposit; expound; flesh out; lucubrate (add details, as to an account or idea; clarify the meaning of and discourse in a learned way, usually in writing).

Where any judge falls under any of the challengeable grounds set forth in section 13, the judge may state the grounds to the Court and remove himself from the case concerned. ( 1 transitive) To present for consideration; to propose. ( 2 intransitive) To begin a journey or expedition. ( 3 intransitive) To start.

set forth-state; set forth one's reasons. exposit, expound. elaborate, expatiate, expound, lucubrate, dilate, flesh out, exposit, enlarge, expand-add details, as to an account or idea; clarify the meaning of and discourse in a learned way, usually in writing; She elaborated on the main ideas in her dissertation.

Verb [edit]. set forth (third-person singular simple present sets forth, present participle setting forth, simple past and past participle set forth). ( 1 transitive) To state; describe; give an account of.
